== Takeovers (2005â2006) ==
== Takeovers (2005â2006) ==
â
[[Image:Inco Mine Manitoba.JPG|thumb|200px|Vale Inco's Thompson Mine in [[Thompson, Manitoba|Thompson]], [[Manitoba]].]]
 
On [[October 11]], [[2005]], Inco announced a friendly takeover bid to buy out the operations of longtime rival [[Falconbridge Ltd.|Falconbridge]] for $12 billion. If approved, the deal would have made Inco the world's largest producer of nickel. [[Xstrata]] (which already owned ~20% of Falconbridge shares) subsequently submitted a [[hostile takeover]] bid for Falconbridge, resulting in a bidding war between Inco and Xstrata. The Xstrata bid was successful, but not before Falconbridge employed a poison pill to delay the acquisition, raising its share price from $28 to $62.50 in the meantime.
On [[October 11]], [[2005]], Inco announced a friendly takeover bid to buy out the operations of longtime rival [[Falconbridge Ltd.|Falconbridge]] for $12 billion. If approved, the deal would have made Inco the world's largest producer of nickel. [[Xstrata]] (which already owned ~20% of Falconbridge shares) subsequently submitted a [[hostile takeover]] bid for Falconbridge, resulting in a bidding war between Inco and Xstrata. The Xstrata bid was successful, but not before Falconbridge employed a poison pill to delay the acquisition, raising its share price from $28 to $62.50 in the meantime.
